original_data.question: A 3-week-old newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often spits up or refuses to eat. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

model_response:
This patient most likely has Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon and rectum. The explosive release of stool following a rectal exam suggests the presence of a rectal impaction. A CT scan of the abdomen would not be helpful in making the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. Transabdominal ultrasonography is not as accurate as a rectal suction biopsy for making the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. Anorectal manometry is used to evaluate the extent of the internal anal sphincter and internal anal os.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: An infant during the first 28 days after birth.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
Interruption or disruption of the intake of food/nutrition.
Abnormal or excessive excitability with easily triggered anger, annoyance, or impatience.
Coming at short intervals or in great quantities.
The forcible expulsion of the contents of the STOMACH through the MOUTH.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Gastrointestinal contents that have returned to the mouth or are ejected beyond the mouth.
The visually perceived property of objects created by absorption or reflection of specific wavelengths of light.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Discarded animal and vegetable matter from a kitchen or the refuse from food preparation. (From Random House College Dictionary, 1982)
The consumption of edible substances.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The event of being born.
Birth at greater than or equal to 37 weeks using best estimated due date.

The act, process, or result of passing from one place or position to another. It differs from LOCOMOTION in that locomotion is restricted to the passing of the whole body from one place to another, while movement encompasses both locomotion but also a change of the position of the whole body or any of its parts. Movement may be used with reference to humans, vertebrate and invertebrate animals, and microorganisms. Differentiate also from MOTOR ACTIVITY, movement associated with behavior.
The section of the alimentary canal from the STOMACH to the ANAL CANAL. It includes the LARGE INTESTINE and SMALL INTESTINE.
Occurring or done each day.
The linear extent in space from one end of something to the other end, or the extent of something from beginning to end.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
A circumferential measurement of the head at the widest point, which is traditionally above the eyebrows.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

The hearing and equilibrium system of the body. It consists of three parts: the EXTERNAL EAR, the MIDDLE EAR, and the INNER EAR. Sound waves are transmitted through this organ where vibration is transduced to nerve signals that pass through the ACOUSTIC NERVE to the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. The inner ear also contains the vestibular organ that maintains equilibrium by transducing signals to the VESTIBULAR NERVE.
Very large in expanse or scope; having great extent from one side to the other.
Any one of five terminal digits of the vertebrate FOOT.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Four or five slender jointed digits in humans and primates, attached to each HAND.
Of or pertaining to the rectum.
Excrement from the INTESTINES, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and BACTERIA of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
The distal segment of the LARGE INTESTINE, between the SIGMOID COLON and the ANAL CANAL.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
To cut a an entity into slices.
The condition of being dilated or stretched.
The segment of LARGE INTESTINE between the CECUM and the RECTUM. It includes the ASCENDING COLON; the TRANSVERSE COLON; the DESCENDING COLON; and the SIGMOID COLON.
One of the parts into which something naturally divides.
The segment of LARGE INTESTINE between the CECUM and the RECTUM. It includes the ASCENDING COLON; the TRANSVERSE COLON; the DESCENDING COLON; and the SIGMOID COLON.
Excrement from the INTESTINES, containing unabsorbed solids, waste products, secretions, and BACTERIA of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM.
The mixture of gases present in the earth's atmosphere consisting of oxygen, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and small amounts of other gases.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
